sources_analysed.description: Entry point for GitHub concepts, account types, onboarding, Git basics, and writing on GitHub.

sources_analysed.description: Overview of GitHub Issues and Projects for tracking work.

sources_analysed.name: GitHub Docs: Planning and tracking with Projects
sources_analysed.description: Detailed docs for the Projects planning and tracking system.

sources_analysed.description: Docs for pull request creation, review, merging, and related workflows.

sources_analysed.name: GitHub Docs: GitHub Actions
sources_analysed.description: Concepts, how-tos, and reference for GitHub Actions workflows and runners.

sources_analysed.description: Overview and configuration of code scanning with CodeQL and related tooling.

sources_analysed.description: Docs for Dependabot alerts, security updates, and version updates.

sources_analysed.description: Docs for secret detection, push protection, and advanced secret scanning features.

sources_analysed.description: Org-scale security configurations, risk assessments, and security campaigns.

sources_analysed.description: Organization creation, membership, roles, settings, and security management.

sources_analysed.description: Administration, IAM, policies, and monitoring for GitHub Enterprise Cloud.

sources_analysed.description: Docs for GitHub Apps, OAuth apps, Marketplace, and related APIs.

sources_analysed.description: Overview and usage of GitHub Copilot, Copilot Chat, CLI, and agents.

sources_analysed.name: GitHub Docs: Codespaces
sources_analysed.description: Docs for GitHub Codespaces environments, lifecycle, dev containers, and org management.

sources_analysed.name: GitHub Docs: Packages
sources_analysed.description: GitHub Packages concepts, registries, permissions, and Actions integration.

sources_analysed.description: Overview and index of all GitHub REST API categories and endpoints.

sources_analysed.name: GitHub Docs: Webhooks
sources_analysed.description: Docs for configuring, validating, and troubleshooting webhooks.

sources_analysed.name: GitHub Docs: Authentication
sources_analysed.description: Authentication methods, 2FA, passkeys, SSH, tokens, and commit signing.

sources_analysed.name: GitHub Docs: Billing
sources_analysed.description: Billing model, product metering, budgets, and billing administration.

sources_analysed.name: GitHub Docs: Documentation home
sources_analysed.description: Top-level navigation to all major GitHub product areas and documentation sections.

likely_uncovered_areas_or_ambiguities: GraphQL API documentation and specific schema details were not directly analyzed; only REST API docs were reviewed.
Limited or no deep coverage of GitHub Discussions, GitHub Pages, GitHub Sponsors, GitHub Education, GitHub CLI, GitHub Desktop, and GitHub Mobile beyond their presence in navigation.
Enterprise Server (self-hosted) features and differences versus Enterprise Cloud are largely out of scope here; focus is on GitHub.com and GitHub Enterprise Cloud.
Internal implementation details (e.g., exact microservices, storage technologies, and job orchestration internals) are not documented and are inferred only at a conceptual level.
Precise default retention periods for all logs, artifacts, caches, and security alerts across products are not fully enumerated in the reviewed docs.
assumptions_made: Descriptions of some well-known features (for example, how pull requests behave in detail, or how Codespaces provides a VS Code-compatible environment) are informed by general product knowledge plus headings in the docs, not full reading of every article.
The mapping between documented REST API categories and underlying services (e.g., actions, codespaces, orgs) is assumed to align one-to-one with backend capabilities.
Where navigation listed articles such as 'About repositories' or 'About issues', their high-level semantics were assumed from titles and context without reading the full article.
Security-related flows (for example, how code scanning integrates with Actions or how Dependabot opens pull requests) are inferred from topic groupings and standard GitHub usage patterns.
The term 'service' or 'module' in the technical components section reflects conceptual groupings, not necessarily distinct deployment units at GitHub.

core_product_capabilities.name: Repository Management & Source Code Hosting
core_product_capabilities.description: Hosts Git repositories on GitHub, allowing users to create, clone, configure, and archive repositories while controlling visibility and collaboration.

main_interfaces.details: Web UI for creating repositories, managing settings, enabling features, and browsing code and history.
Git CLI interacting with GitHub remotes for cloning, pushing, and fetching, plus GitHub CLI for repo administration.
REST API endpoints under /repos for programmatic repository lifecycle and configuration.

key_data_involved: Repositories and repository metadata
Commits, branches, and tags
Files, blobs, and trees
Releases and release assets
Repository visibility and collaborator permissions
Repository rulesets and branch protection configuration
security_relevant_traits: Controls repository visibility (public, private, internal) and who can read or write code.
Supports branch protection rules and rulesets that gate merges on reviews, status checks, and other conditions.
Allows privileged actions such as deleting, transferring, or restoring repositories.
Releases and artifacts may contain production binaries; improper access settings can expose sensitive assets.

evidence.title: GitHub Docs: Repositories
evidence.summary: Outlines creating and managing repositories, settings, branches, releases, and archiving.

evidence.title: GitHub Docs: Creating and managing repositories
evidence.summary: Defines repositories and describes creation, cloning, limits, and visibility.

core_product_capabilities.name: Issue Tracking & Work Management with GitHub Issues
core_product_capabilities.description: Enables tracking of bugs, tasks, ideas, and feedback using issues, labels, milestones, and templates, tightly integrated with repositories and pull requests.

main_interfaces.details: Issues tab in repositories and organization-level issues views, including templates, labels, and milestones.
REST API endpoints for issues, comments, labels, milestones, and issue events.
GitHub CLI commands for creating, listing, and updating issues from the terminal.

key_data_involved: Issues and their titles, bodies, and states
Comments and reactions
Labels and milestones
Assignees and linked pull requests
Issue templates and form metadata
security_relevant_traits: Issues may hold sensitive operational details or security reports if not triaged properly.
Permissions for creating, editing, and deleting issues are controlled by repository and org settings.
Issue templates can enforce structured information (e.g., requiring security impact details).

evidence.title: GitHub Docs: About issues
evidence.summary: Explains how GitHub Issues are used to track ideas, feedback, tasks, and bugs.

evidence.title: GitHub Docs: Issues overview
evidence.summary: Lists key guides for creating issues, linking PRs, and configuring templates.

core_product_capabilities.name: Project Planning & Reporting with GitHub Projects
core_product_capabilities.description: Provides adaptable projects that track work across repositories using tables, boards, and roadmaps, with custom fields, charts, and automation.

main_interfaces.details: Projects views (table, board, roadmap) within organizations, users, and repositories.
REST and GraphQL APIs for managing Projects items, fields, and views.
Automations that connect Projects to issues, pull requests, and Actions workflows.

key_data_involved: Project items (issues, pull requests, draft items)
Custom fields (text, number, date, single-select, iteration)
Views, filters, and layouts
Charts and insights derived from project data
security_relevant_traits: Project visibility and access can expose or restrict cross-repo planning information.
Automations can add or modify items based on triggers, potentially moving sensitive work into broader visibility if misconfigured.
Export functionality allows bulk extraction of project data, which could include sensitive work descriptions.

evidence.title: GitHub Docs: Planning and tracking with Projects
evidence.summary: Describes Projects, custom fields, views, automations, insights, and access controls.

core_product_capabilities.name: Pull Requests & Code Review Workflow
core_product_capabilities.description: Supports proposing, reviewing, and merging code changes via pull requests, including branch management, reviews, conflict resolution, and merge strategies.

main_interfaces.details: Pull requests tab in repositories for creating PRs, reviewing diffs, and merging.
REST API endpoints under /pulls for PR lifecycle and review comments.
GitHub CLI commands for creating, checking out, and merging pull requests from the terminal.

key_data_involved: Pull requests and their metadata
Diffs, commits, and review comments
Review states and approvals
Merge commits or rebase/squash merge results
Status checks and code scanning results attached to PRs
security_relevant_traits: Branch protection and required reviews can gate merges into protected branches.
Status checks and code scanning alerts can enforce security and quality before merge.
Permissions for merging and force-pushing are tightly controlled and auditable.

evidence.title: GitHub Docs: Pull requests overview
evidence.summary: Index of documentation for committing changes, collaborating with pull requests, resolving conflicts, and reviews.

evidence.title: GitHub Docs: About pull request reviews
evidence.summary: Describes how reviews work and how they integrate into pull request workflows.

core_product_capabilities.name: Automation with GitHub Actions (User Perspective)
core_product_capabilities.description: Allows users to define workflows as code in YAML that run on events or schedules to build, test, deploy, and automate tasks across the software lifecycle.

main_interfaces.details: Actions tab in repositories and organizations for configuring workflows, viewing runs, and logs.
Workflow YAML files under .github/workflows in repositories.
REST API endpoints for workflows, runs, artifacts, and runners.

key_data_involved: Workflow definitions (YAML)
Jobs, steps, and logs
Secrets and environment variables
Artifacts and caches
Runner configuration and labels
security_relevant_traits: Workflows execute arbitrary code on GitHub-hosted or self-hosted runners, requiring careful secret handling.
Organization and enterprise policies can restrict which actions and runners are allowed.
GITHUB_TOKEN and other credentials are scoped and rate-limited but still powerful if exfiltrated.
Actions can deploy to production systems or modify repositories, making workflow definitions security-critical.

evidence.title: GitHub Docs: GitHub Actions overview
evidence.summary: Introduces GitHub Actions, workflows, runners, and basic CI/CD use cases.

evidence.title: GitHub Docs: Workflow syntax for GitHub Actions
evidence.summary: Defines the YAML schema and capabilities available in workflows.

core_product_capabilities.name: Cloud Development Environments with GitHub Codespaces
core_product_capabilities.description: Provides cloud-hosted development environments backed by dev containers that can be created per branch or template and accessed from the browser or local IDE.

main_interfaces.details: Codespaces entry points in repository and user menus for creating, opening, and managing codespaces.
GitHub CLI commands to create and connect to codespaces from a terminal.
Integration with VS Code and other IDEs via remote development plugins.

key_data_involved: Codespace instances, including filesystem state and ports
Dev container configuration (Dockerfiles, devcontainer.json)
Repository source code and checked-out branches
Secrets and environment variables scoped to codespaces
Usage metrics for billing and quotas
security_relevant_traits: Codespaces run user code on GitHub-managed infrastructure; access to private repositories and registries must be controlled.
Org and enterprise policies can restrict machine types, regions, network access, and retention.
Secrets used within codespaces (development environment secrets) must be managed and can be audited.
Security logs and audit logs capture access and activity related to codespaces.

evidence.title: GitHub Docs: What are GitHub Codespaces?
evidence.summary: Introduces Codespaces, their features, and typical workflows.

evidence.title: GitHub Docs: Codespaces overview page
evidence.summary: Lists guides for codespace lifecycle, dev containers, and org-level management.

core_product_capabilities.name: Package Management with GitHub Packages
core_product_capabilities.description: Provides package registries for multiple ecosystems (container images, npm, Maven, NuGet, etc.), integrated with repositories and GitHub Actions.

main_interfaces.details: Package views on user, organization, and repository pages for publishing, browsing, and configuring packages.
REST API endpoints for listing and managing packages and their versions.
Ecosystem-native tooling (npm, Maven, Docker, etc.) configured to use GitHub Packages registries.

key_data_involved: Packages and versions across supported ecosystems
Package metadata (names, descriptions, licenses)
Package visibility and access control configuration
Authentication tokens for publishing and consuming packages
Links between packages and source repositories
security_relevant_traits: Packages may be deployed to production systems; unauthorized modification can be supply-chain compromising.
Access control and visibility settings determine who can publish or download packages.
Actions workflows used to publish packages must protect credentials and enforce review.
Dependency links from repositories feed into dependency graph and security analysis.

evidence.title: GitHub Docs: Introduction to GitHub Packages
evidence.summary: Explains what GitHub Packages is and how to publish, view, install, and delete packages.

evidence.title: GitHub Docs: Working with the Container registry
evidence.summary: Describes using GitHub's container registry to store and manage Docker and OCI images.

core_product_capabilities.name: Developer Assistance with GitHub Copilot
core_product_capabilities.description: Offers AI-powered coding assistance, chat, CLI, code review, and agents that help generate, explain, and modify code and configuration.

main_interfaces.details: IDE integrations (e.g., VS Code, JetBrains) that surface Copilot completions and chat.
Copilot CLI for using AI assistance from the terminal.
Copilot Chat and coding agents in the GitHub.com web UI for repositories and pull requests.

key_data_involved: Source code and configuration files in repositories or open in the IDE
Prompts and conversation history with Copilot Chat
Repository context (issues, PRs, docs) used as context for suggestions
Usage and billing data for Copilot licenses
security_relevant_traits: Copilot suggestions can introduce insecure patterns if not reviewed; code review remains essential.
Copilot access and usage are controlled via org and enterprise policies, including which repositories are in scope.
Copilot code review and coding agents can open or modify pull requests automatically on a userâ€™s behalf.
Organizations can manage data usage and model selection for compliance requirements.

evidence.title: GitHub Docs: GitHub Copilot documentation
evidence.summary: Landing page for Copilot docs including chat, CLI, coding agent, billing, and customization.

evidence.title: GitHub Docs: About GitHub Copilot Chat
evidence.summary: Describes Copilot Chat capabilities and how it augments coding workflows.

core_product_capabilities.name: Code Scanning for Static Application Security Testing
core_product_capabilities.description: Runs static analysis (primarily via CodeQL) on repositories to detect code vulnerabilities and quality issues, surfacing alerts and gating merges.

main_interfaces.details: Security tab in repositories and organizations showing code scanning alerts and configurations.
Actions workflows or external CI jobs that run CodeQL analysis and upload SARIF results.
REST API endpoints for querying code scanning alerts and uploading SARIF results.

key_data_involved: Source code analyzed by CodeQL or other scanners
Analysis results and SARIF files
Code scanning alerts and triage metadata
Security configurations and query suites
security_relevant_traits: Alerts can be configured to block pull request merges via branch protection.
Default and advanced setups can be applied at scale via org and enterprise policies.
Integration with external CI systems and SARIF uploads extends trust boundaries.
Copilot Autofix can propose remediation changes, which must be carefully reviewed.

evidence.title: GitHub Docs: Finding security vulnerabilities with code scanning
evidence.summary: Explains code scanning availability, setup modes, and alert management.

core_product_capabilities.name: Dependency & Supply Chain Management with Dependabot
core_product_capabilities.description: Monitors project dependencies for known vulnerabilities and out-of-date versions, generating alerts and automated pull requests to update dependencies.

main_interfaces.details: Security alerts views for Dependabot alerts and configuration screens in the repository or organization.
Dependabot configuration files in repositories controlling ecosystems, update schedules, and policies.
REST API endpoints for Dependabot alerts and repository access configuration.

key_data_involved: Dependency manifests and lockfiles
Vulnerability advisories and alerts
Dependabot configuration (update cadence, allowlists/blocklists)
Automated PRs with dependency updates
Metrics for alerts and auto-triage rules
security_relevant_traits: Dependabot alerts highlight exploitable vulnerabilities in dependencies.
Auto-triage rules and auto-dismissal must be configured carefully to avoid suppressing important alerts.
Automated PRs can update code and workflows; review and testing gates are crucial.
Integration with private registries and self-hosted runners widens the trust boundary.

evidence.title: GitHub Docs: Keeping your supply chain secure with Dependabot
evidence.summary: Describes supported ecosystems, alerts, auto-triage rules, security and version updates, and troubleshooting.

core_product_capabilities.name: Secret Scanning & Push Protection
core_product_capabilities.description: Detects leaked credentials and secrets in repositories and optionally blocks pushes that contain patterns resembling secrets, supporting custom patterns and partner integrations.

main_interfaces.details: Secret scanning configuration and alert views under the Security section of repositories and organizations.
Push protection enforcement during git push from local development tools, and command-line prompts for bypass or remediation.
REST API endpoints for secret scanning alerts and push protection configuration.

key_data_involved: Repository content and history
Detected secret tokens and metadata
Secret scanning alerts and states
Custom and provider secret patterns
Push protection configuration and bypass decisions
security_relevant_traits: Can proactively block pushes that include secrets, preventing leakage into history.
Supports custom patterns and delegated bypass and dismissal, which govern who can override protections.
Copilot secret scanning features can generate patterns and detect generic secrets, introducing AI-based detection into the pipeline.
Org-level secret risk assessments summarize exposure and inform adoption of advanced protections.

evidence.title: GitHub Docs: Keeping secrets secure with secret scanning
evidence.summary: Explains secret scanning, push protection, supported patterns, alert management, and advanced features.

administrative_and_operational_capabilit.name: Organization & Team Administration
administrative_and_operational_capabilit.description: Manages organizations, membership, teams, repository access, and organization-wide settings and security policies.

main_interfaces.details: Organization settings UI covering members, teams, repositories, policies, and security settings.
REST API endpoints for organizations, members, teams, and org-level settings.
REST API endpoints for teams and their memberships.

key_data_involved: Organization accounts and profiles
Members, outside collaborators, and roles
Teams and team hierarchies
Repository access policies and base permissions
Org-level feature flags and restrictions (Actions, Pages, Discussions, Codespaces)
security_relevant_traits: Controls who can create repositories, change visibility, delete or transfer repos, and manage actions like forking.
Team-based permission models and roles affect access to code, issues, and security data.
Org-level settings govern 2FA requirements, SSO, commit signoff, and model usage.
Org audit logs provide detailed records of configuration and access changes.

evidence.title: GitHub Docs: Organizations overview
evidence.summary: Defines organizations and describes membership, settings, and best practices.

evidence.title: GitHub Docs: Organizations index
evidence.summary: Lists documentation for roles, membership, repository access, security, and settings.

administrative_and_operational_capabilit.name: Enterprise Account & Policy Administration (GitHub Enterprise Cloud)
administrative_and_operational_capabilit.description: Provides enterprise accounts that own multiple organizations, centralizing governance, identity, policies, data residency, and auditing for large customers.

main_interfaces.details: Enterprise account settings for managing orgs, policies, IAM, data residency, and audit logs.
REST API endpoints covering enterprise teams, enterprise-level metrics, and administration.
Global webhooks configured at the enterprise scope for monitoring events across all organizations.

key_data_involved: Enterprise account metadata
List of organizations and their settings
Enterprise roles and delegations
Compliance reports and audit logs
Enterprise-wide policies for Actions, security, and repositories
Data residency configuration and region assignments
security_relevant_traits: Enterprise-level policies can enforce or relax security and governance controls across all child organizations.
Enterprise IAM configuration (including SAML and EMU) centralizes identity across many users.
Audit logs at enterprise scope enable forensics and regulatory compliance.
Data residency configurations influence where user and repository data is stored and processed.

evidence.title: GitHub Docs: Enterprise administrators overview
evidence.summary: Introduces GitHub for enterprises and the role of enterprise accounts.

evidence.title: GitHub Docs: Enterprise Cloud admin index
evidence.summary: Lists enterprise-level docs including IAM, policies, monitoring, and data residency.

administrative_and_operational_capabilit.name: Organization-Scale Security Configuration, Risk Assessment & Campaigns
administrative_and_operational_capabilit.description: Allows organizations to define and apply security configurations, run secret and vulnerability risk assessments, and manage remediation campaigns at scale.

main_interfaces.details: Org-level security center views and configuration pages for security configurations and risk reports.
REST API endpoints for code security configurations and campaigns.

key_data_involved: Security configurations applied to repositories
Lists of repositories and their security feature status
Secret risk assessment data and reports
Vulnerability exposure metrics and prioritization data
Security campaigns and their progress
security_relevant_traits: Centralizes enabling and configuring features like code scanning, Dependabot, and secret scanning across repositories.
Secret risk assessments reveal where secrets may have leaked and help justify adoption of push protection.
Security campaigns orchestrate large-scale remediation efforts with tracking and best practices.
Misconfiguration of security configurations can unintentionally disable key protections at scale.

evidence.title: GitHub Docs: Securing your organization
evidence.summary: Covers enabling security features, managing configurations, secret risk assessments, vulnerability exposure, and campaigns.

administrative_and_operational_capabilit.name: Authentication & Account Security Management
administrative_and_operational_capabilit.description: Provides mechanisms to authenticate users and services (passwords, passkeys, 2FA, SSH, personal access tokens, SSO) and manage security of accounts and tokens.

main_interfaces.details: User account security settings for passwords, two-factor authentication, passkeys, SSH keys, and tokens.
REST API endpoints for authentication, credential scopes, and token permissions.
SSO integrations via SAML/OIDC and enterprise-managed user provisioning via SCIM.

key_data_involved: User identities and account metadata
Authentication credentials (password hashes, passkeys, SSH keys, tokens)
2FA configuration and recovery codes
Security logs of sessions and sign-in attempts
SSO and SAML assertion metadata
security_relevant_traits: Supports mandatory 2FA enforcement at org and enterprise levels.
Fine-grained personal access tokens and GitHub App tokens have scoped permissions and expiration.
Security logs and audit logs capture authentication events and credential changes.
Passkeys and WebAuthn-based authentication reduce reliance on passwords.

evidence.title: GitHub Docs: Authentication index
evidence.summary: Lists docs for account security, 2FA, passkeys, SSH, and commit signing.

administrative_and_operational_capabilit.name: Billing & Usage Management
administrative_and_operational_capabilit.description: Manages billing accounts, payment methods, plans, budgets, and usage for metered GitHub products such as Actions, Codespaces, and Copilot.

main_interfaces.details: Billing settings and usage dashboards for organizations and enterprises.
REST API endpoints for budgets and usage data.

key_data_involved: Billing accounts and contacts
Product usage metrics (Actions minutes, Codespaces hours, Copilot seats)
Budgets, alerts, and cost centers
Invoices and payment transactions
security_relevant_traits: Billing roles determine who can change plans, payment methods, and budgets at org or enterprise scale.
Budgets and alerts help detect anomalous usage that could indicate abuse (e.g., malicious Actions workloads).
Billing data may be subject to compliance and privacy requirements depending on geography and customer type.

evidence.title: GitHub Docs: Introduction to billing and licensing
evidence.summary: Explains the billing platform, key concepts, and managing spending.

evidence.title: GitHub Docs: How GitHub billing works
evidence.summary: Describes what is billed, when, and how to track usage.

api_surface_and_integrations.name: GitHub REST API
api_surface_and_integrations.description: Exposes a comprehensive HTTP-based API for interacting with nearly all GitHub resources, including repositories, issues, pull requests, actions, security, and administration.

main_interfaces.details: Versioned REST API endpoints under api.github.com organized by resource categories.
Official SDKs such as Octokit libraries for various languages built on the REST API.

key_data_involved: All core GitHub resource types (users, orgs, repos, issues, PRs, actions, security alerts, etc.)
Authentication credentials (PATs, GitHub App tokens, OAuth tokens)
Webhooks configuration and delivery data when managed via API
Rate limit metadata and audit-relevant request details
security_relevant_traits: Authentication and authorization mirror the web UI, but automated access increases impact of credential compromise.
Rate limits protect the platform but also act as signals of potential abuse.
Fine-grained scopes and permission models for tokens limit which endpoints can be called.
API versions and breaking changes are managed explicitly to reduce integration risk.

evidence.title: GitHub Docs: About the REST API
evidence.summary: Introduces the REST API, its resources, and versioning.

evidence.title: GitHub Docs: REST API index
evidence.summary: Lists all REST API categories and endpoints by feature area.

api_surface_and_integrations.name: Webhook Event Delivery
api_surface_and_integrations.description: Delivers HTTP callbacks to customer-provided endpoints when events occur in GitHub (such as pushes, issues, and workflow runs), enabling event-driven integrations.

main_interfaces.details: Repository, organization, app, and enterprise-level webhooks configured via the UI.
REST API endpoints for managing webhook configurations and deliveries.

key_data_involved: Event payloads containing repository, org, user, and activity data
Webhook endpoint URLs and shared secrets
Delivery logs, response codes, and timestamps
Redelivery attempts and failure metadata
security_relevant_traits: Webhook payloads may contain sensitive information about code, issues, and security events.
Secrets (HMAC signatures) and TLS must be used to authenticate deliveries.
Misconfigured endpoints or forwarding tooling can leak data outside intended boundaries.
Redelivery and troubleshooting features can be used to replay events into test systems.

evidence.title: GitHub Docs: Webhooks overview
evidence.summary: Explains creating, handling, validating, and troubleshooting webhooks.

evidence.title: GitHub Docs: Webhook events and payloads
evidence.summary: Documents supported webhook events and their payload schemas.

api_surface_and_integrations.name: GitHub Apps & OAuth Apps Platform
api_surface_and_integrations.description: Provides an extensibility platform via GitHub Apps and OAuth apps, enabling fine-grained, token-based integrations that can act as bots, tools, or login providers.

main_interfaces.details: App registration and installation configuration pages for GitHub Apps and OAuth apps.
REST APIs for GitHub Apps, installations, and Marketplace operations.
GitHub App webhooks delivering app-specific event payloads.

key_data_involved: App registrations and metadata (name, permissions, webhook URL)
Installation records across users and organizations
App tokens and user access tokens
Marketplace listing and billing data for paid apps
security_relevant_traits: GitHub Apps use fine-grained permissions and short-lived tokens, reducing blast radius compared to classic OAuth apps.
App installations can be scoped to specific repositories and organizations, and are reviewable by admins.
Privileged GitHub Apps can have elevated capabilities and require special oversight.
Misconfigured apps or over-broad permissions can still lead to major compromise if tokens are abused.

evidence.title: GitHub Docs: About using GitHub Apps
evidence.summary: Explains what GitHub Apps are and why to use them.

evidence.title: GitHub Docs: About creating GitHub Apps
evidence.summary: Describes registering and building GitHub Apps with fine-grained permissions.

background_jobs_and_automation.name: Event-Driven Workflows with GitHub Actions Runners
background_jobs_and_automation.description: Executes workflows on hosted or self-hosted runners in response to repository and organization events, schedules, or manual triggers.

main_interfaces.details: Workflow YAML files defining jobs that run asynchronously on events or schedules.
Actions run history, logs, and artifact views in the repository and org UI.
REST API endpoints for workflow runs, jobs, artifacts, and runners.

key_data_involved: Job execution metadata and logs
Artifacts and caches generated by workflows
Runner configuration and labels
Triggers and event payloads associated with each run
security_relevant_traits: Jobs may access secrets and tokens; logs and artifacts can inadvertently store sensitive data.
Runner policies determine where code runs and what network access it has.
Misconfigured triggers (e.g., on pull_request from forks) can be abused for secret exfiltration if not mitigated.
Limits and quotas help mitigate abuse and manage cost.

evidence.title: GitHub Docs: Concepts for GitHub Actions
evidence.summary: Describes workflows, runners, security, metrics, and billing concepts.

background_jobs_and_automation.name: Automated Dependency & Security Remediation Jobs
background_jobs_and_automation.description: Runs background jobs to analyze dependencies, raise alerts, and open or update pull requests to remediate vulnerabilities and keep dependencies current.

main_interfaces.details: Dependabot configuration files and security settings that schedule background checks.
Security alerts views and Dependabot job logs in the repository UI.

key_data_involved: Dependency manifests and lockfiles across repositories
Vulnerability advisories and CVE metadata
Background job run logs and status
Automated PRs and their merge status
security_relevant_traits: Background jobs regularly check for and surface new vulnerabilities as advisories are published.
Auto-updating dependencies via PRs reduces time-to-remediation but must be controlled to avoid breaking changes.
Metrics and auto-triage rules can prioritize vulnerabilities based on exploitability and usage context.
Background jobs may require access to private registries and self-hosted runners, expanding trust boundaries.

evidence.title: GitHub Docs: Working with Dependabot
evidence.summary: Details workflows for dependency updates, including job logs and troubleshooting.

background_jobs_and_automation.name: Security Scanning, Push Protection & Policy Enforcement Pipelines
background_jobs_and_automation.description: Runs automated pipelines that scan code for vulnerabilities and secrets, enforce merge protections, and block risky pushes based on configured policies.

main_interfaces.details: Code scanning and secret scanning jobs triggered by pushes, pull requests, and schedules.
Security views for code scanning and secret scanning alerts, and branch protection settings.

key_data_involved: Source code and configuration scanned for issues
Security alerts and their triage state
Branch protection and merge protection settings
Push protection events and bypass reason data
security_relevant_traits: Merge protection based on code scanning alerts or required checks can prevent known-vulnerable code from landing in protected branches.
Push protection can block secrets from entering history at all, not just alert after the fact.
Org and enterprise policies define which protections are mandatory and where exceptions are allowed.
Central dashboards aggregate these pipeline results for monitoring risk posture.

evidence.title: GitHub Docs: Managing your code scanning configuration
evidence.summary: Documents configuring merge protection based on code scanning results.

evidence.title: GitHub Docs: Working with secret scanning and push protection
evidence.summary: Explains push protection workflows and remediation for leaked secrets.

background_jobs_and_automation.name: Projects & Codespaces Automation and Prebuilds
background_jobs_and_automation.description: Automates project management (for example, auto-updating fields and views) and prebuilds Codespaces environments to speed up developer onboarding and workflow.

main_interfaces.details: Projects automation configuration within project settings and views.
Codespaces prebuilds configuration in repository and organization settings.

key_data_involved: Project items and field values updated by automations
Automation rules and conditions
Codespaces prebuild configurations and VM images
Metrics on prebuild usage and performance
security_relevant_traits: Automations can change visibility or status of work items, indirectly affecting who sees sensitive tasks.
Codespaces prebuilds may include compiled dependencies or cached secrets access, which must be carefully configured.
Org-level restrictions on machine types, retention, and networking affect how prebuilds operate.
Misconfigured automations could inadvertently move sensitive items into broader visibility or delete critical data.

evidence.title: GitHub Docs: Automating your project
evidence.summary: Describes built-in automations and API-based automation for Projects.

evidence.title: GitHub Docs: Prebuilding your codespaces
evidence.summary: Explains prebuilds, their configuration, and management.

services_or_modules.name: Repository & Git Service
services_or_modules.description: Stores Git repositories and provides operations for cloning, pushing, pulling, and browsing code and history.

services_or_modules.name: Issues, Projects & Collaboration Service
services_or_modules.description: Handles issues, comments, labels, milestones, and Projects data and views.

services_or_modules.name: Pull Request & Review Service
services_or_modules.description: Manages pull requests, reviews, review comments, merge strategies, and status checks integration.

services_or_modules.name: Actions & Workflow Service
services_or_modules.description: Schedules and executes workflows on runners, tracks runs, logs, artifacts, and caches.

services_or_modules.name: Codespaces Service
services_or_modules.description: Provision and manages dev containerâ€“based development environments, including lifecycle and prebuilds.

services_or_modules.name: Packages & Container Registry Service
services_or_modules.description: Hosts package registries for various ecosystems and integrates them with repositories and workflows.

services_or_modules.name: Security & Advanced Security Service
services_or_modules.description: Encompasses code scanning, secret scanning, Dependabot, security configurations, and security campaigns.

services_or_modules.name: Organizations & Enterprise Admin Service
services_or_modules.description: Maintains orgs and enterprise accounts, roles, policies, and audit logs.

services_or_modules.name: Identity & Authentication Service
services_or_modules.description: Provides authentication mechanisms, token issuance, and SSO/SAML/SCIM integrations.

services_or_modules.name: Billing & Metering Service
services_or_modules.description: Measures usage for metered products, calculates billing, and surfaces budgets and cost centers.

services_or_modules.name: API Gateway & REST Layer
services_or_modules.description: Exposes GitHub resources via versioned REST endpoints, applies auth, rate limiting, and validation.

services_or_modules.name: Webhook Delivery Service
services_or_modules.description: Queues and delivers webhook events, tracks delivery status, and supports retries and inspection.

services_or_modules.name: Apps & Integrations Platform
services_or_modules.description: Manages GitHub Apps, OAuth apps, Marketplace, and associated permissions and webhooks.

services_or_modules.name: Copilot & Models Service
services_or_modules.description: Surfaces AI models via IDE integrations, chat, CLI, and coding agents, and integrates with repositories.

storage_and_logs.name: Git Repository Storage
storage_and_logs.description: Stores Git objects and refs backing repositories and associated metadata.

storage_and_logs.name: Metadata Datastores
storage_and_logs.description: Hold issues, PRs, projects, orgs, security alerts, and other relational or document-style metadata.

storage_and_logs.name: Actions Artifacts & Logs Storage
storage_and_logs.description: Persists workflow logs, artifacts, and caches for troubleshooting and reuse.

storage_and_logs.name: Codespaces Storage & Snapshots
storage_and_logs.description: Maintains persistent volumes and snapshots for codespaces, including dev container images.

storage_and_logs.name: Security & Audit Logs
storage_and_logs.description: Stores organization and enterprise audit logs and account security logs for compliance and forensics.

storage_and_logs.name: Billing & Usage Datastores
storage_and_logs.description: Aggregate metered product usage and billing-related data, including budgets and reports.

external_systems.name: Identity Providers (IdPs)
external_systems.description: External SAML/OIDC identity systems used for SSO and Enterprise Managed Users.

external_systems.name: Payment Providers and Azure Billing
external_systems.description: External billing and payment platforms handling credit card and Azure subscription payments.

external_systems.name: Customer CI/CD and Deployment Systems
external_systems.description: External systems triggered by GitHub webhooks or Actions to deploy code or run additional checks.

external_systems.name: Private Package Registries
external_systems.description: Third-party or self-hosted registries used with Dependabot and security features.

external_systems.name: Secret Scanning Partners
external_systems.description: Service providers that receive notifications about leaked secrets for revocation and remediation.

data_flows.name: Code Push and Repository Update Flow
data_flows.description: Developers push commits to GitHub; the repository service updates Git data, which triggers downstream events such as Actions workflows, webhooks, code scanning, secret scanning, and project automations.

data_flows.name: Issue and Project Management Flow
data_flows.description: Users create and update issues and project items via UI or API; changes propagate to notifications, dashboards, charts, and, when configured, Actions-based automations.

data_flows.name: Pull Request & Review Flow
data_flows.description: Pull requests aggregate commits; reviewers provide feedback; status checks and scans run; once criteria are met under branch protection rules, merges update protected branches.

data_flows.name: Security Scanning & Alerting Flow
data_flows.description: Code scanning and secret scanning jobs analyze repositories; results are stored as security alerts and surfaced in dashboards and via APIs; policies can block merges or pushes based on these results.

data_flows.name: Dependency & Vulnerability Management Flow
data_flows.description: Dependabot and security services ingest dependency manifests and vulnerability advisories; alerts are raised and automated PRs created; merged updates feed back into dependency graph and risk metrics.

data_flows.name: Webhook & Integration Flow
data_flows.description: Events from repositories, orgs, or apps are serialized into payloads and delivered via webhooks; external systems respond and may call back into the REST API to perform actions.

data_flows.name: Billing & Usage Flow
data_flows.description: Usage from Actions, Codespaces, Copilot, and other products is recorded and aggregated; budgets and alerts are evaluated; billing statements are generated and exposed through UI and APIs.

privileged_operations: Changing repository visibility, deleting repositories, or transferring repository or organization ownership.
Creating, editing, and deleting organization- or enterprise-level policies for Actions, security features, and repository management.
Configuring enterprise IAM, including SAML SSO, Enterprise Managed Users, and SCIM provisioning.
Managing security configurations and applying or detaching them from large sets of repositories.
Enabling or disabling powerful features like Codespaces, GitHub Actions, and GitHub Copilot for an organization or enterprise.
Managing billing settings, budgets, and payment methods that control access to paid features.
user_configurable_logic: Workflow logic defined in GitHub Actions YAML files that can execute arbitrary code, deploy systems, or modify repositories.
Project automations that update fields, move items between views, or archive items based on conditions.
Dependabot configuration that controls how and when dependency update jobs run and which dependencies are included.
Security configurations and rulesets that define when code scanning, secret scanning, and other protections are applied and how merge or push protections behave.
Webhooks and GitHub Apps that execute user-defined code in response to GitHub events.
auth_and_identity_behaviours: Support for multiple authentication factors (passwords, 2FA, passkeys) and recovery methods, with optional mandatory 2FA for organizations.
Use of personal access tokens, fine-grained tokens, and GitHub App tokens with scoped permissions and expiration for API and Git operations.
Single sign-on with SAML/OIDC and Enterprise Managed Users centralizes identity and may enforce login via IdP.
Session and device verification flows (e.g., sudo mode, new-device verification) to mitigate account takeover.
Management and rotation of SSH keys, deploy keys, and GPG keys used for code signing and repository access.
logging_and_audit_behaviours: Organization and enterprise audit logs record administrative actions, security configuration changes, and significant repository events.
Account-level security logs record sign-in events, credential updates, and token usage.
Codespaces and Actions provide logs of environment usage and workflow runs, respectively, for troubleshooting and incident response.
Billing reports and usage logs help detect anomalous usage that could be associated with abuse or compromise.
failure_modes: Workflow runs can fail due to configuration errors, unavailable runners, or rate limits, potentially blocking deployments or quality/security checks.
Webhook deliveries can fail due to endpoint errors or network issues; without proper retries or monitoring, integrations may silently break.
Code scanning and secret scanning may be misconfigured or disabled on some repositories, leaving gaps in coverage.
Dependabot jobs can stop generating updates due to misconfiguration, registry access issues, or hitting limits, leaving dependencies stale.
Codespaces creation or prebuilds may fail due to dev container misconfiguration, quota exhaustion, or network restrictions.
Authentication failures (e.g., misconfigured SAML, revoked tokens) can lock users out or cause service interruptions if not mitigated by recovery mechanisms.

open_questions.question: What are the precise data residency guarantees and tenant isolation properties for all GitHub features (Actions, Codespaces, Copilot, Packages) when using Enterprise Cloud with data residency?
open_questions.context: The Enterprise Cloud admin docs describe data residency generally, but per-feature behavior and any exceptions are not fully detailed in the reviewed sections.
related_capabilities: Enterprise Account & Policy Administration (GitHub Enterprise Cloud)
Cloud Development Environments with GitHub Codespaces

open_questions.question: How exactly are GitHub Models and Copilot services architected relative to core GitHub data stores, and what data is retained or used for training versus only for inference?
open_questions.context: The Copilot and GitHub Models docs describe usage and customization, but do not deeply document internal data flows or retention policies in the sections analyzed.

open_questions.question: What are the default and maximum retention periods for all classes of logs, artifacts, caches, and security alerts across Actions, Codespaces, security products, and audits?
open_questions.context: Individual docs mention retention configuration for some artifacts and logs, but a consolidated matrix of defaults and limits was not found.
related_capabilities: Event-Driven Workflows with GitHub Actions Runners
Cloud Development Environments with GitHub Codespaces
Security Scanning, Push Protection & Policy Enforcement Pipelines

open_questions.question: How do fine-grained personal access token permissions map exhaustively to REST API endpoints, and how are edge cases handled when multiple permission sources overlap?
open_questions.context: The REST auth docs list endpoint sets and required permissions, but a full mapping and conflict resolution behavior across token types and roles was not fully explored.
